title: Rename `to_upper` to `upper` and `to_lower` to `lower`
body: From discussion here: https://github.com/mthom/scryer-prolog/discussions/2129

title: CI: compile wasm separately; default 22.04; matrix
body:
This makes wasm build separately as its own architecture target in the build matrix, and compiles directly instead of using wasm-pack.

⚠️ This also changes the test step to not fail the build because it currently fails on wasm. ⚠️

I think this is a reasonable intermediate step until the wasm tests are fixed, after which we can remove the `|| echo "::warning` at the end of line 66 so that failing tests will fail the build again.

In particular, I would expect this command to succeed without producing any errors or warnings:

```
cargo test --target wasm32-unknown-unknown --no-default-features --all --verbose
```

title: Reify (^)/2 & small changes
ENHANCED: Omit unnecessary residual constraints in disentailed reified (//)/2
body:
Example:

    ?- #\ 0#=(Y// -1)/0.
    %@    clpz:(Y in inf..sup).

This addresses #2104.

title: Queue morphed propagators to give them a chance for propagation
body: This addresses #2096.

title: ENHANCED: use (+)/2 to express unary minus
body:
This makes answers a bit shorter and more readable.

Example:

    ?- X #= -Y.
       clpz:(X+Y#=0).

This addresses #2058.

title: attach the propagator to Y
ENHANCED: Omit projection of morphed (^)/2 in disentailed constraints.
body:
Example:

    ?- B #<==> (0^Y/0) #= Z.
       B = 0, clpz:(Y in 0..sup), clpz:(Z in inf..sup).

title: FIXED: Queue triggered propagators to be processed after pexp/3 finishes
body:
If reification constraints (such as reified equality) are triggered here, then they may wish to disable this propagator and remove attributes from auxiliary variables. If the pexp/3 propagation is interrupted for that purpose, then the attributes will be unintentionally reattached by the following fd_put/3 calls in this propagator. We must ensure that this propagator completely finishes, so we queue the triggered propagators for later processing.

geq/2 implements propagator activation outside the queue, and thus should not be used in propagators in the way it was used here.

pexp/3 by itself may not seem particularly important. However, it can arise by metamorphosis from Var*Var. Example:

    ?- A#<==> -1#=C*C, C in 0..1.
       A = 0, clpz:(C in 0..1).

This addresses #2089.

@notoria: This may be interesting for you! I hope the description makes sufficiently clear what the issue is here: `geq/2`, as a regular Prolog predicate, does not have access to the implicit propagation queue, and so cannot insert the triggered constraints in the queue that is currently being worked off. Instead, it spawns a separate queue and immediately activates the triggered propagators. After this is done, further code in the propagator where this was started may accidentally "undo" the desired removal of attributes from auxiliary variables, by reattaching attributes to them that previous propagators have already removed.

title: ENHANCED: Remove no longer needed morphed propagators.
body:
This addresses all remaining cases from #2083, excepting (//)/2:

    ?- #\ 1#=(X*X)/0.
       clpz:(X in inf..sup).

    ?- #\ 1#=(X+X)/0.
       clpz:(X in inf..sup).

Still remaining:

    ?- #\ 0#=(Y// -1)/0.
       clpz:(-1*Y#=_A).

title: Use the same queue for variables in reified constraints
body: This addresses #2084.

title: Add phrase_from_stream/2 to library(pio)
body:
I wanted to learn how to use global variables in Prolog (`bb_get/2` and `bb_put/2` specifically), and thought this was a good application. It was very, _very_ hard but I think I did it.

In my opinion `phrase_from_stream/2` is the most useful predicate that wasn't yet implemented. I already stumbled into many situations where it would have been incredibly useful, mainly dealing with sockets.

In this implementation it still uses the old `stream_to_lazy_list/2` for repositionable streams, as I bet it's way more efficient than whatever shenanigans I'm doing in the other case, especially for large files. For non-repositionable streams it stores the data from the string in a buffer to enable backtracking, as suggested in #1146.

I'm not sure if this can handle arbitrary binary data, as it uses `partial_string/3` and `partial_string_tail/2`, but the old `stream_to_lazy_list/2` also used `partial_string/3`, so at least I'm not regressing here.

The buffer is a partial string, and I'm not sure what this means for the performance of this for long streams. I'm currently using a custom `string_get_n_chars/4` implementation that is recursive and therefore _does not_ acess the buffer with random access. I know that Scryer uses a very efficient internal representation for partial lists, so maybe there is some way to get a substring more efficiently than this if this ever presents itself as a important performance problem in the future.

Closes #1146.

title: Improvements to dif/2
body:
These changes make so that `dif/2` passes all [these tests](https://www.complang.tuwien.ac.at/ulrich/iso-prolog/dif). I made a test battery to check that and it's included with this PR. 

Honestly, I don't really understand what I did here. I guess it involves removing the involved goals from the `dif/1` attribute and then reapplying them with `dif/2` after the unification. Doesn't look very efficient. I also feel I may have broken something else while doing it, but at least the tests pass.

Closes #1382.
Closes #1433.
Closes #1956.

title: Simplify fn maybe
body:
`maybe` can be a one-liner. Noticed when casually browsing #2025.

Also fixes some whitespace errors.

title: Use a SeedableRng to generate random numbers
body:
Until now, set_random wasn't really useful (#1985) because we were not using that random generator in `maybe/0`. With this, we can get deterministic random numbers based on a seed. By default, it will just take a seed from the system, as before.

```
?- use_module(library(random)).
   true.
?- random_integer(0, 100, N).
   N = 13.
?- set_random(seed(42)).
   true
;  ... .
?- random_integer(0, 100, N).
   N = 57.
?- random_integer(0, 100, N).
   N = 21.
?- random_integer(0, 100, N).
   N = 55.
?- set_random(seed(42)).
   true
;  ... .
?- random_integer(0, 100, N).
   N = 57.
?- random_integer(0, 100, N).
   N = 21.
?- random_integer(0, 100, N).
   N = 55. 
```

title: use version from crates.io
Upgrade dashu and make the related code more idomatic.
body: This PR should fix https://github.com/cmpute/dashu/issues/33. I also made several improvements on the code to make the usage of `dashu` more idomatic. Besides the floored division of big integers is also implemented.

title: fix Docker image
body:
The Docker image is broken with the error message:

    scryer-prolog: error while loading shared libraries:
    libssl.so.1.1: cannot open shared object file: No such
    file or directory

We use the base base image `debian:stable-slim` and in the background a new Debian version was marked stable (bookworm), which has libssl3 instead of libssl1.1 installed.

I downgraded the base image to the previous stable version (bullseye), which seems to fix the issue.

title: detect and prevent concurrent AtomTable use
body: The AtomTable currently uses a global variable to store the pointer to the AtomTable's block base. This means that only one AtomTable can be used at once as otherwise Atoms may be looked up in the wrong AtomTable. This PR adds logic to detect an AtomTable being created while one already exists. When this is detected it panics with a descriptive error message, to prevent more obscure problems.

Replace rug with dashu

This gets rid of the msys2 dependency on windows with a pure rust implementation of big numbers.

Package updated to make this possible currently forked:
https://github.com/coasys/dashu
https://github.com/coasys/libffi-rs

title: remove another !/0 which is now no longer necessary due to improved indexing
ENHANCED: use newly available read_term_from_chars/3 for better errors
body:
Examples, previously:

    $ scryer-prolog -g "member(X,Ls"
    ?-
    $ scryer-prolog -g "member(X,Ls)"
    member(_542,_543) causes: error(existence_error(procedure,member/2),member/2)
    ?-

Now:

    $ scryer-prolog -g "member(X,Ls"
    "member(X,Ls" cannot be read: error(syntax_error(incomplete_reduction),read_term_from_chars/3:0)
    $ scryer-prolog -g "member(X,Ls)"
    member(X,Ls) causes: error(existence_error(procedure,member/2),member/2)
    ?-

This also addresses https://github.com/mthom/scryer-prolog/issues/1185.

       N = 3.

title: Programatic use of Machine / Scryer as library
ENHANCED: improved determinism of member/2
body:
Example:

    ?- member(X, "abc").
    %@    X = a
    %@ ;  X = b
    %@ ;  X = c.

This addresses #750.

make double_quotes write option not dependent on double_quotes flag
body:
This gives consistent results without depending on another flag.

I think this semantics is better, since it gives more predictable results, and it also simplifies the internal implementation, letting us move more of the logic to Prolog.

Also, it now behaves as it was already documented.

title: Revise iso_conformity_tests.pl to remove unnecessary spaces

title: Allow comparisons with stream terms
body: It fixes https://github.com/mthom/scryer-prolog/issues/1855 by giving stream terms a way to be compared similar to atoms and compounds.

title: advertise newly achieved strong syntactic conformance: all current tests pass
body: This addresses an important aspect of #1777.

title: remove now unneeded check
Improvements to needs_bracketing/2
body:
Here are a few further improvements to `needs_bracketing/2`. Notably, we now get for example: 
?- X = -->(a,b,c).
   X = -->(a,b,c).
Also, I removed 2 branches that I think are not necessary. In addition, I have switched the if-then-else to disjunctions to make the code shorter and more readable, without introducing any non-determinism in the toplevel itself, because `needs_bracketing/2` is always used in a "cutting" context, where alternative solutions are not considered anyways. Please review, and merge if applicable. Many thanks!

title: bracket all operators that are direct operands of (=)/2
body: This addresses #804.

title: Automate ISO syntax conformity tests
body:
The ISO syntax conformity tests of [https://www.complang.tuwien.ac.at/ulrich/iso-prolog/conformity_testing](https://www.complang.tuwien.ac.at/ulrich/iso-prolog/conformity_testing) are here introduced as Prolog predicates run by the `run_tests/0` predicate. 

Currently, none of the tests fail when `-f` is used on this branch.

title: remove unneeded single quotes
use copy_term_nat/2
Fix tags trigger; bump MSRV to 1.65
body:
Changes the CI trigger to automatically create release when a tag that matches `v*` is pushed to the repo.

Also bumps MSRV to 1.65, because  [the version of rug in cargo.lock was increased to 1.19](https://github.com/mthom/scryer-prolog/commit/7f45ac3f7a947e3d7b6556cddea9110622b675fd#diff-13ee4b2252c9e516a0547f2891aa2105c3ca71c6d7a1e682c69be97998dfc87eL1611-L1616), which [only supports rust 1.65 and newer](https://gitlab.com/tspiteri/rug#version-1190-news-2023-01-06). This was causing the build to fail.

title: MODIFIED: read_line_to_chars/3 is now called get_line_to_chars/3
body:
Dear all,

in continuation of #1228, this PR renames the last remaining erroneously called "read..." predicate to **"get..."**, namely **`get_line_to_chars/3`**.

The only currently existing use of this predicate I am aware of occurs in [`newscryer.pl`](https://www.metalevel.at/prolog/faq/newscryer.pl), which I hope is the only program that needs to adapt.

Please adjust your programs if necessary, and forgive the backwards incompatible change.

Thank you and all the best,
Markus

Release notes

Sourced from openssl's releases.

openssl-v0.10.55

What's Changed

  • Fix warnings from BoringSSL on Rust 1.70 by @​alex in sfackler/rust-openssl#1948

  • add Nid::SM2 and pkey Id::SM2 by @​zh-jq in sfackler/rust-openssl#1962

What's Changed

  • Check for OPENSSL_NO_RC4 when using EVP_rc4 by @​oskirby in sfackler/rust-openssl#1910

  • add X509::pathlen by @​zh-jq-b in sfackler/rust-openssl#1916
  • Add bindings to SSL_bytes_to_cipher_list by @​RoastVeg in sfackler/rust-openssl#1921

  • add other name support by @​huettner94 in sfackler/rust-openssl#1915

  • add Dsa with some helper functions by @​reaperhulk in sfackler/rust-openssl#1937
  • reimplement Dsa::generate in terms of generate_params/generate_key by @​reaperhulk in sfackler/rust-openssl#1938
  • Added DER serialization for DSAPrivateKey by @​alex in sfackler/rust-openssl#1939
  • version bump 0.9.88 and 0.10.53 by @​reaperhulk in sfackler/rust-openssl#1940

New Contributors

  • @​oskirby made their first contribution in sfackler/rust-openssl#1910
  • @​zh-jq-b made their first contribution in sfackler/rust-openssl#1916
  • @​RoastVeg made their first contribution in sfackler/rust-openssl#1921
  • @​huettner94 made their first contribution in sfackler/rust-openssl#1915

Dependabot commands and options
You can trigger Dependabot actions by commenting on this PR: - `@dependabot rebase` will rebase this PR - `@dependabot recreate` will recreate this PR, overwriting any edits that have been made to it - `@dependabot merge` will merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot squash and merge` will squash and merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot cancel merge` will cancel a previously requested merge and block automerging - `@dependabot reopen` will reopen this PR if it is closed - `@dependabot close` will close this PR and stop Dependabot recreating it. You can achieve the same result by closing it manually - `@dependabot ignore this major version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this major version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this minor version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this minor version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this dependency` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this dependency (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) You can disable automated security fix PRs for this repo from the [Security Alerts page](https://github.com/mthom/scryer-prolog/network/alerts).

title: Multiple fixes for http libraries
body:
* use reqwest for http_open (still uses Hyper underneath)
* use Hyper 1.0.0-rc3 for server
* Modify all internal handling of server

In general we try to use less parts of Tokio (which can be problematic right now and actually it introduced a complex data race) while preparing Scryer to use Hyper 1.0 once it reaches final state. We use reqwest instead of Hyper for the client because in Hyper 1.0 they removed the high-level Client module we were using, reqwest is from the same authors, higher level but for our use case, still fine.

Note that none of this changes the external API that http_open and http_server define.

title: ADDED: dif_si/2
body:
Source: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/20223390/prolog-a-person-is-a-sibling-of-himself

In Scryer Prolog, this is actually not needed, since Scryer Prolog provides dif/2 in library(dif). However, it is still useful to provide dif_si/2 for two reasons:

  1) to more easily port code from systems where only dif_si/2 is available
  2) to provide correct disequality in other systems that adopt this library

title: Fix to_upper/to_lower when string is instantiated
body:
Now:

```
?- use_module(library(charsio)).
   true.
?- char_type(a, X).
   X = alnum
;  X = alpha
;  X = alphabetic
;  X = alphanumeric
;  X = ascii
;  X = ascii_graphic
;  X = hexadecimal_digit
;  X = lower
;  X = octet
;  X = prolog
;  X = symbolic_control
;  X = to_lower("a")
;  X = to_upper("A")
;  false.
?- char_type(a, to_upper("A")).
   true.
?- char_type(a, to_upper("B")).
   false.
?- char_type(a, to_upper('A')).
   false.
?- char_type(a, to_upper([X])).
   X = 'A'.
```

title: Change ref for `publish-unit-test-result-action`
body:
I worked with the author of the `publish-unit-test-result-action` to deliver an enhancement that makes it work better for the scryer-prolog project, but I forgot to scrub the testing branch reference out of the action before it was merged. This is the cause of some of the [recent PR builds failing](https://github.com/mthom/scryer-prolog/actions/runs/4771903258/jobs/8484131136?pr=1792#logs):

> Error: Unable to resolve action `EnricoMi/publish-unit-test-result-action@branch-publish-summary-on-fork`, unable to find version `branch-publish-summary-on-fork`

This changes it to use the master branch again. Sorry!

title: library(charsio): add to_upper and to_lower
body:
It adds uppercase and lowercase transformations based on #748 

```
?- use_module(library(charsio)).
   true.
?- char_type(x, Type).
   Type = alnum
;  Type = alpha
;  Type = alphabetic
;  Type = alphanumeric
;  Type = ascii
;  Type = ascii_graphic
;  Type = lower
;  Type = octet
;  Type = prolog
;  Type = symbolic_hexadecimal
;  Type = to_lower("x")
;  Type = to_upper("X")
;  false.
?- char_type('ß', Type).
   Type = alnum
;  Type = alpha
;  Type = alphabetic
;  Type = alphanumeric
;  Type = lower
;  Type = octet
;  Type = prolog
;  Type = to_lower("ß")
;  Type = to_upper("SS")
;  false.
?- char_type('X', Type).
   Type = alnum
;  Type = alpha
;  Type = alphabetic
;  Type = alphanumeric
;  Type = ascii
;  Type = ascii_graphic
;  Type = octet
;  Type = prolog
;  Type = to_lower("x")
;  Type = to_upper("X")
;  Type = upper
;  false. 
```

The transformations use strings as the Rust API returns a string for the uppercase or lowercase of a single char. Of course, if you're using a language when this doesn't happen, you can always use:

```
?- char_type('X', to_upper([Upper])).
   Upper = 'X'.
```
